author: oaklandmatt
content:
Oliver power tools and kshmr are the most useful and most modern packs. Not sure what kind of music you're making but for my workflow I like doing whatever I feel on a production and then having quick "modern" drum sounds I can reach for that immediately can put things into the present.

I'm doing a production right now for a UK artist where they gave me a throwback sounding demo, but I know the artist is a young 2023 female pop star. So I did a bunch of organic shit (acoustic through my 67, some live claps, shit like that), then I threw some kshmr and oliver loops in to just see what the hybrid of classic and modern sounds like. Production is basically done now

author: BatMeckley
content:
I worked with a band at the very beginning that was a three piece with VERY specific rules. 

1) all songs had to be under 2:45
2) guitars and vocals could be doubled for tone, but not parts.
3) bassist sang lead, if there was a harmony the guitarist (not a gifted singer) had to sing it, if there was a third part the drummer had to sing it (couldn’t sing at all)
4) record couldn’t take more than a week to record/mix 

It was the project that convinced Luke I could be a producer; his fav record id done up to that point.

There’s a real value to putting strict limitations on your art, it often brings the most clarity and creativity. Side note: they were terrible technical musicians but just fucking AWESOME.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
@BatMeckley is the resident Grammy Loser on this topic, but I’ve made a decent living doing some indie and major label stuff as a vocal producer. 

Deliverables really depend on the producer you’re working with. In my experience it’s 50/50 whether they want tuned or raw, comped or all the takes- etc. 

The key things that keep me getting called are, in no particular order:

Communication. Everybody knows what to expect and what is to be expected. 

Professionalism. The room is clean, mics are up, lighting is right, session is loaded. 

Intuition. All the artistic/personal things. Making the artist feel safe enough to be dangerous, knowing how hard you can push them to get a take, knowing where the line is between their vision and yours, etc…

Sonics. I want my artists to feel expensive when they’re recording, so getting the mic and cue mix right is everything. 

Speed. A comp up by the time they’re done tracking, a quick shine to make it feel special, and a bounce for them to take with them.

Everything else is on a per session basis. I can deliver a fully mixed/tuned vocal and everything in between, so it all depends on communication ahead of time.

author: BatMeckley
content:
Things that I didn’t work on that blow my mind vocally: When the Circus Comes by Los Lobos. A lot of the 1975 stuff is really really well put together vocally. It’s Not Living if its Not With You is full of incredible vocal tricks. Worth repeated listenings. Youngblood by 5SOS is a modern song really well put together. Think Andrew Watt handled the vocals on that and did a fantastic job getting the take out of Luke. Dance Hall Days by Wang Chung is always a good reference. Mercy Street by Peter Gabriel (the whole SO record) pretty unfuckwithable. Bang Bang is always a great reference because you can really show a singer the difference between a Jessie J and an Arianna. Comes in handy in sessions a lot.

If you’re looking for creative, the whole Dissociatives record is a constant reference. I’d start with “Horror With Eyeballs”

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Really well framed and important questions here. 

I’ve heard your music, and so first let me say that you’re on the path. This is the work. This is the practice. Just like yoga or meditation or basketball. 

Second, let me say, again, there’s no secret knowledge. There’s only showing up, paying attention, and doing the work consistently. 

Consistency is the only actual key to success. 

So when you look at your finished projects you can’t think about them as failures, only as rungs on the latter you’re climbing. And the only way to see what’s what is to KEEP CLIMBING.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
Most things that have been said, I agree with. But I think they are secondary to a much more fundamental thing. The producer is the one who gets it done to the highest standard. 

This is what people get wrong about Rick Rubin. While he talks a lot about listening and "ways of being," that's not what makes a great producer. That's his personal application. What people miss is when he says "we work on the project until everyone involved thinks it's as good as it can possibly be. If we don't all think that *it's not finished*."

Phil Spector's version was "it's finished when *I* think it's as good as it can possibly be." But it's the same fundamental thing: across the finish line with highest possible quality.

Taste but with a relentless will to execute at the highest level.

author: cian riordan
content:
Aside from the usual discussion about headphone preferences and HRTF, I’ll give you my experience with them.

I bought them a few years ago with the intention of just having a baller set of headphones for a bunch of travel I had coming up. I had tried them once at @oaklandmatt’s place and wasn’t super impressed... just thought they sounded like hyped headphones. But I really wanted something with killer noise cancellation and something to potentially reference Spatial mixes. After purchasing, the more I used them, the more I fell in love with listening to music on them. I realized quite early on that there was a lot of parity between how things sounded in the APMaxes vs. my PMC 6-2s… similar low end presentation, similar high end. But just genuinely enjoyed listening to music on them.

I was traveling for thanksgiving last year and a last minute mix opportunity came up for some video game trailer. Not my normal speed but they were up shits creek with a deadline and the money was good… so I mixed the whole thing start to finish on my laptop with the Airpods. I was a little sheepish about sending off un-vetted mixes, but the clients loved it and I saved the day. I curiously took a listen when I got back to my studio after the holiday and was very surprised that the mix was 98% there. There was maybe a small low end tweak I could’ve made, but by and large, the mixes translated incredibly well. 

Now I use them much more for odd tasks, usually revisions and printing sessions. I can be on my couch on my laptop running files down with transparency mode on, still hanging with my family while watching a show, and lock in with noise cancelling when I need to focus.

For $600 they’ve been a massive value-add to my work flow.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
There is a much longer answer, but essentially you learn that they are not opposites. You can overthink repeatedly on your way to finishing. 

It's not a straight line where you're productively working toward better. It's about always striving toward the absolute best you can get by exhausting your ideas and making the best decision you can in the moment. 

Art is subjective, so there's actually no "better." If you build up all these little skills (from keyboard shortcuts to emotional vulnerability in a writing session) and add that to repetitions, all you need is a relentless will to finish at the highest standard and you'll have a serious career.

Spoiler alert: the relentless will to finish is the hard part.

author: Zack Hames
content:
You’re gonna hate this. But the best way is to just get more reps to get faster and better. 10,000 hours, no shortcuts.

But more actionable advice - stick to a slim number of EQ and Compressor plugs and just use those. For example 99% of my mixes just use pro q3, API-2500, and Kush AR-1. The idea being minimize variables and decisions, and use stuff you know ridiculously well.

Production side, I find having go to sounds, samples, and instruments (hardware or software) well learned and ready to go shortens the path from opening your project to creating music. For me, this is taking my free time to mess with my MPC and explore samples, or to create patches on my synths to become more intertwined with my instruments. This is separate from the actual “I’m gonna make a song today” process.

Ultimately…make a song in 8 hours as many days as you can. If you TRY every day, that’s better than nothing. By the end of a month, even if you only made FOUR tracks…that’s better than nothing and it just adds up.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Has anyone checked out the massive update that Ableton just released for their *Learning Synths* website? 

I wish I didn't know a thing about synths so that I could experience it fresh. It's a brilliant site and a great resource for learning the fundamentals of synthesizers. *Strong* recommend, even if you already know that domain.

They've done something really cool, in that you can play a patch in the browser as they're teaching you, pop the hood and tweak it if you want to go deeper *and then* you can download the patch you've been playing with as a Live session that you can then open in Live and continue creating with it.

That might sound pretty simple, but the execution is brilliant. It's very fun.

https://learningsynths.ableton.com/en/get-started

author: Slow Hand
content: Hey. Do what you've got to do. author: BatMeckley
content:
That’s so funny. I JUST had this experience a month or so ago and hit up @oaklandmatt for tips. I can say that in my personal experience working with boy (and girl) bands, there’s a couple things that come into play. First, you have to do your research and see how many are singers, and what they’re good at. This last project I did all 5 dudes were RIDICULOUSLY good singers, but one had a particularly sweet falsetto, one had a really good rasp in their voice, etc. Once I discovered that it was much easier to figure out who got what parts and what features. It’s a nice tact to make sure everyone has at least a moment where they shine. Other ensemble groups I worked with only had 50% of the band be actual “singers” and the other members were there for other reasons. It’s good to know what’s what before going in. 

The second part that comes into play (sadlly) is the inevitable politics. Someone usually thinks they’re the star (they might be right). Usually the label has a favorite or two (I actually had an A&R person pull me aside before a session once and say “we’re gonna pull _____ solo in a year, so make sure to give them all the good parts”). I’ve found that having them all there at the same time has the bonus of them challenging and supporting each other (no one wants to suck in front of their team) but also make sure you have something fun for the other 4 or 5 to do cause they’ll get bored waiting for their turn at the mic quick. 

Lastly, preparation is key. Have tracks already laid out ready to record before they get there. Anticipate what you’ll need. Template it out. Having 4 or 5 singers is 4 or 5 times the work. Little things like creating new tracks or whatever become real time suckers. It’s a lot of different singers to cram into a day or two so be extra prepared.

Hopefully some of that helps.

author: BatMeckley
content:
There’s one specific actress/singer I’ve worked with a few times, and the second time she brought her mom over while we were tracking. Every time I complimented her after a take, she screwed up the next one. If I said a take was bad the next one would be great. The session quickly devolved in to me just saying increasingly awful things after every take, much to her mom’s delight who was laughing on the back couch.

I’ve said this over and over again on this server, but people skills and just sheer musical awareness and taste trump technical ability and gear every time (the how vs the why). If I’m needing Kirk to record an incendiary angry solo in the middle of a heavy, emotional song, I’m probably not gonna set up flowers in the studios and kick it off with a warm stone massage.  Your job as a producer is to get the best out of the artist, and a good producer will have a feel for what that specific artist needs.(A Rick Rubin specialty).

author: LAPhill
content: The hard truth is that, if you're going to be a producer recording your own parts, then it's your responsibility to figure out how to make them bang. And learning how to quickly and efficiently work around your limitations is part of the gig. Get really good at knowing where you can punch to hide the seams of comping, regardless of the type of part. Retune the guitar to make chord shapes easier. Split up the part. If you practice THOSE editing skills, your workflow will speed up tremendously. There's no need to concern yourself with being able to play it in one go, or at all, unless you're going to perform it live.

author: LAPhill
content: I’ve worked with many, many of the top session players in LA (and around the world). Trust me, they don’t get it in one take either. But they know how not to waste time, punch only what they need to, and move on.

author: LAPhill

In the same way that sometimes the rough mix wins, sometimes that loop that you grabbed just to kick off ideas ends up unbeatable. Rerecord with different sounds, trying to match or improve the feel, but there was something about the way those Splice loops interacted that couldn't be beaten. Or just isn't worth the effort because now everyone is focused on making sure the vocal is perfect and the track is working. 

I'd take the best version of the song over some self-imposed creative high ground any day.

author: BatMeckley
content:
I think these things are cumulative… so…
Vintech was able to sell a ton of units because on the NAMM floor their pre was indistinguishable from a 1073 costing 4 times as much. But, if you took one home and used it as your one pre across 100 tracks of your masterpiece, even your parents are going to hear the difference between it and a vintage neve. That small 5% difference really added up at the end. I’m sure after floor two of the leaning tower of Pisa the engineers we’re like “lookin good boss! 👍🏼 “ and it wasn’t til they compounded their error that people started to panic.
If you’re making tracks 95% in the box with samples and soft synths and then just drop a featured rapper on top of it, it’s probably not going to matter if you use a Scarlett or an Apollo or an Apogee. But if you’re a professional mixer constantly printing stuff 100x a session through outboard gear you’re going to notice a difference I can guarantee you. Or if you’re doing a Low record where there’s only three elements and one of them is the most gifted voice of a generation, the gear is going to matter a lot more than if you’re squeezing a TikTok star into 37 plugins and then into a 150 track mix.

So at the end of the day, much like producing, songwriting or pretty much everything else in life, it’s that old prayer of strength to change the things you can, the grace to accept the things you can’t, and the most important bit that everyone seems to skip over, THE WISDOM TO KNOW THE DIFFERENCE. 

Do what works for you, and clearly, I sweat the details enough to notice that the algorithms are different, or Cians dangerous was down a half a db on one side, but also, when to actually use that information to actually make the actual point. Otherwise you end up being a photographer that does nothing but collect backs and lenses but never actually takes a photo.

author: BatMeckley
content:
Again, this comes down to the why. There’s absolutely a time for “fuck you, pay me”. But knowing when the time is is key.

Just being honest, I’ve seen far more people tank their career by fighting for a credit or a fee than I’ve seen people solidify their career by doing so. If you’re going to make an issue out of something, you better be sure you’re worth the issue.

At no point am I saying to be taken advantage of. What I’m saying is our perception of value to a project and other peoples perception of our value to a project rarely line up 1:1. It’s a really quick way to find out what our actual worth is in the biz.

author: BatMeckley

author: BatMeckley
content:
Brothers and sisters of the ‘cord, when you find yourself collaborating with other people on a project, for the love of God don’t send an mp3. Send a .wav whose master bus processing is properly compensated for so that your collaborator can drop your file into their session at beat one and it will line up perfectly. Do not make them guess. No, the transient of your kick isn’t exactly on the 1. 

Let it be written.

author: Zach Hughes
content:
Wanted to share some thoughts spurred on by a recent experience on here. So a local artist has hired me to produce two of her songs. Vibe is singer-songwriter, soul, RnB.

We tracked drums, bass, and keys live in the studio OD'd to scratch tracks we cooked up together. The scratch tracks / demos were just guitar vocal and we were really relying on the players to fill out the arrangements, but we knew more would be added down the line.

All the players were incredible. Could singe your eyebrows off with technical prowess and shredtastic chops. Tracks turned out great, still working on the arrangement, but..

This project has got me thinking more about the importance of how you present a song to session musicians and the 'space' you ask them to fill in a production. As well as the changing dynamics project to project affected by a revolving cast of participants, more fleshed out demos, etc... I find this a really interesting topic. Curious if anyone in the group has any unique experiences or insights whether as a producer or a musician.

I've found that the more I flesh out demos with the artist beforehand the more bound and limited the session players we bring in are based off our decisions. This can make ODs more efficient, add a clearer direction, but can also remove the opportunity for the player to really add something special. Sometimes I don't want to be too suggestive b/c I want the players to have more of a blank canvas to work with.

author: BatMeckley
content:
I mean, I feel like the question kinda answers itself. If you want session musicians to execute your vision, give them bumpers and tell them what it is. If you want them to add their own flavor, take the reigns off and tell them to have at it. Both ways are useful, and a good session musician will be adept at doing both. Bad session musicians will try to cross those lines one way or the other.

In my sessions i almost always have a clear vision of what I want, have whoever I brought in execute it, and then I save a little time for them to do their thing, and seek a bit of magic that I might have missed. It all depends on the particular killer you’ve brought in.

author: chris_donlin
content: Today I said something very simple and honestly think it solved most of the issue. We were getting some scratch vocals down and I suggested we use that as the scratch vocal time to experiment with how we want to capture it. I tend to overlook the importance of a good, intentional scratch, because you might get usable stuff. But then they can sit with it and tweak if need be. I think it’s fair to take responsibility for not pushing him harder for a more intentional scratch. It made the rest of our writing session today go much smoother and just more exciting. Appreciate everyone’s input. In good spirits!

author: Ross Fortune
content:
If you’re on a UAD system, Virtual channels work in Pro Tools to significantly cut software inst monitoring latency.

Once you’ve set up the virtual channel in UAD console and PT IO, you can use it as the output of your software instrument track and it’ll negate any latency introduced downstream in the PT session. Not sure if the same in ableton, but worth a shot.

author: BatMeckley
content:
I’m KINDA kidding, we’ve gone over this a lot on here… I much prefer the standalone workflow, but there’s a ton of people that swear by it in plugin form, it just doesn’t work for me that way, and I get different sounding results partly because of workflow and partly because we’ve verified they actually sound different (different algorithms). 

Melodyne is an incredible tool, but it’s not without its quirks. The first thing is: the correction is only as good as the detection… so it’s worth a quick run through to make sure it’s mapped the vocal take properly.  Sometimes it gets a syllable or two in the wrong octave, and rarer times it’ll get it wrong a fourth or fifth off. I’m not sure the process for correcting that in the plug in off the top of my head. Once you’ve got the detection right…

The  next step is understanding how we fundamentally sing; a note tends to have a front end or consonance, the meat of the note, and then lastly the tail. You want to separate the meat of the note out, and concentrate on tuning that. Also remember that the “blob” is just an average of the tuning info in it, meaning if your note slides from C to E, melodyne will correct that blob to D. (I hope that makes sense.)

author: BatMeckley
content:
Sure, but I’ve always stood on the whole point of a producer is to have an objective opinion about a subjective medium. It was posited that someone wouldn’t work with someone because of their opinion, and I was countering that I’d want to work with MB ENTIRELY because of his opinion. He has made records I think are GREAT. He says music I don’t think is great isn’t great.

There’s this toxic positivity of not letting anyone say “hey this sucks”. And I think that’s a garbage way to move forward. Yes, that sucks. Why? Ok. Let’s apply that observation to this project so hopefully it sucks less. I care more about identifying what makes something mediocre so we can fix it than I do about making people feel better about the mediocrity.

author: cian riordan
content: I worked on the “Daddy’s Home” album with Jack and I really appreciated how extreme he was with his panning in the rough mixes. I’ll always try and balance out with something opposite if I can, and often times if something is hard panned, I’ll have a sans amp or mono compression send up the middle that I can anchor the sound in if it starts to sound lopsided.

author: BatMeckley
content:
My experience has been that people over think the panning tbh. I don’t think talking about 5% or 10% moves on individual instruments really makes a huge difference; theres a reason why great mixers like CLA and Jerry Finn are essentially LCR. 

I’m talking more about having something historically stereo like drums, or even an entire mix, tightening THAT macro down to 75% or 50%. Who knows tho, maybe moving the flute track from 65% right to 70% right during an outtro really takes the project over the finish line, but again, in my experience, that’s never been the bottle neck.

author: Zach Hughes
content:
I've been melodyning vocals for a ten song album past couple weeks and feel like I've leveled up my chops significantly. I'm no Beckley, but browsing whats been previously shared here and trial and error has been the mechanism of growth for me.

I kinda had the note separation tool workflow down from work in other programs. I've been experimenting with the time tool and attack speed tool as well as formant shifting to mask when the tuning becomes more audible than I'd like. That's probably where I'd pinpoint the level up for me personally. That and trying to be more conscious about not relying too much on the graphical UI. Unless it's something that really calls for hard tuning I lean towards wanting it to feel invisible / natural. Im realizing more what parts of the note actually need to be more 'on' and which can be more 'off' or just left alone. That and letting notes naturally drift to become more sharp as they tail off. If I'm too heavy handed it starts to feel lifeless to me. I'm also appreciating more the nuance of how one might approach different genres or styles with melodyne. Its humbling how powerful the program really is.

There've been a few moments with the attack speed tool that have felt like magic curing some subtleties of the performances that bug me, but I don't feel super confident that I have a grasp on that one yet. I've been working in standalone and importing a REF mix. For some reason I feel more confident dealing with esses in protools with RX or clip gain than I do melodyne idk why. Some frustrations have been flipping back and forth between tracks when tuning multiple files feels real clunky. I might be missing something about how best to do that. I wish, like with RX monitor, you could hear the vocal through your mix chain when tuning (is that possible?). Being able to rename exported files would be nice too like in RX.

author: Iwan Morgan
content: All this Hi-hat chat reminds me of a method i’ve not seen used before anywhere else.  I made a record in Nashville a few years ago with engineer Mark Nevers (Bill Callahan, Bonnie Prince, Lambchop etc) and instead of using click tracks he had in his template a load of shakers, side sticks and percussion loops which he had recorded all set with Elastic Audio and Tick based processing. What this meant was he could create a shaker type click just by changing the blend between the samples and pushing the tempo up or down. It worked really well on what was an acoustic based record. The players loved it, and I swear they got master takes quicker without being bludgeoned by the normal click.  Anyone done this before? Is it a Nashville thing?

author: Deleted User
content:
I had this one particular vocal session where I was fucking up and all my comments were messing with the artist’s flow. So about an hour or two into the session, I got real with the artist and said “I feel like I’m being too much of a control-freak and my comments seem to be distracting you. Why don’t we take a break? When we come back, let’s forget about everything I mentioned earlier and see how things come out when you express freely. I have a feeling that it’s gonna turn out way better. I’m sorry, I think I got it your way” 

then after the break, the artist started nailing the takes. Not in the exact way I imagined, but in the best possible way that we were capable of THAT DAY. 

Since then, I decided to let go of control a bit more and let the artists do their thing as much as I can. I started developing ears for hearing what artists can work on before the session to get a better recording to my best of ability (if I get to know them before the sesh). I would only mention the simple things that can be improved with small adjustments short-term. That way the session can be more experimental and wild as opposed to fault-finding.

author: BatMeckley

author: Slow Hand
content:
While we’re on the topic of Bowie, he was a seriously, *seriously* funny motherfucker. His cameo appearance on the show ‘Extras’ (and the behind the scenes documentary) comes to mind.

There’s a great story from an engineer who was on a session w/ Bowie: 

David was leaving the studio and the engineer asked him “What would like me to do while you’re out?” and David’s reply was “Just turn up the good stuff and turn down the bad stuff.”

Of course it’s hilariously pithy, but the more that I think about it the more I come to realize how deceptively profound it is as well. I think of it often while I’m working.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Another example:

On Brett’s last record, he did a demo with a co-writer of a song I loved. he tracked vocals with me, and I suggested the track needed a Mayer style guitar solo, so I played it. When Dann Huff heard it he told Brett “we’ll just upgrade Noah’s track to Master Scale. It’s not gonna get any better than that.”

When they went into the studio, they ended up taking the Mayer idea all the way, and the whole thing kinda went Country “Don’t Trust Myself.” They couldn’t do a Mayer solo on top of a Mayer vibe cause it would go from inspired by to straight derivative. 

My solo didn’t make the record, and I didn’t get any production credit. But the guy who did the demo did. I did get some BGVs on it and paid accordingly. All that felt right to me.

author: BatMeckley

author: Zach Hughes
content: I also struggle to find a balance between focusing on production work and my songwriting. I was focused heavily on production work over the summer and then when my schedule loosened up in the Fall I started writing for my next album. I had done a little brainstorm session with chatGPT actually to help me create a daily schedule oriented solely around writing which was pretty helpful. But even when still in the production grind I like having guitars laying around so I can grab one when I take a break or bring on in the house with me. If you have the flexibility, w/o compromising deadlines, I've found it helpful to leave room to indulge the moments when songs / melodies / lyrics pop into my head even when my expectation that day was to work on a mix or other production. Be interrupted by the song and push everything else back an hour and see what happens.

author: Eric Martin
content:
Click is freedom, No click is freedom, it can be done well, but instrumental maturity to know when to and when not to.

My artist project gets a lot of tracks recorded without click and I always lock a tempo map in to the original performance. 

I always have a physical drum machine ready to program a beat because some people need that vs a static click to play along with, the feel can be transformative when there’s a downbeat and upbeat present with groove already in it, even if it IS on the grid and not swung.

Whenever I get left field projects, I always talk with the artist about what they ideally want and then I kind of just try a couple versions where I’m doing big changes. 

If it’s poorly recorded, I’ve found success on finding a deliberate style for the one “poor sounding” element in a song—be it vocals, drums etc and then stylizing the elements around them. If the drums sound meh, blow em up—make ‘em loud, distort, double/warp, chop.

author: Josh Bowman
content: I do backblaze for all my project drives, work off of a 1tb Samsung t5 for my current mixes, and then have all archived mixes on a 12TB 3.5” external drive, and have a cloned safety of both archived and current projects on another western digital desktop drive I update nightly or sometimes every other day. Backblaze is always also running in the background so if I get lazy one night and that’s the day my hard drives all explode there’s still a pretty good chance it’s backed up to the cloud.  So everything is on two physical drives plus back blaze. Also all deliverables live on my Dropbox (finished mixes and stems etc). So if I lost the multi tracks and all my data the final deliverables are archived on there too.

author: Deleted User
content:
I feel you, especially in boom bap there's a lot that goes into that drunken swing feel. Same with tradition African groove. Easiest way is to load up a clip or loop from a drummer you like and extracting groove templates. You can quantize to the groove of your favorite drummer or a drum loop you dig. This will get you the results, but groove is a never ending journey of learning. Editing groove to make it feel the way you want to feel takes an understanding of what makes things groove one way or the other. It can be accents, dynamics, lengths of the notes, how much you deviate from the grid or what subdivisions you're on, and how the timing offsets rub and interact with each other in the whole instrumentation. Some drummers have really solid quintuplet swing, so instead of doing tripplet swing they'll play on the downbeat and the 3rd or 4th note of quintuplet. For this you can listen to guys like Nate Smith, he plays swings differently live than recordings- he drags and pushes the kicks and snares in recordings but for live, he only swings hats so there's more steady groove for other musicians to grab onto. 

On the other hand, for playing the grooves yourself- I find it helpful to dance and groove to the rhythms as much as I can to absorb the feel and internalize them. But in order to play ahead or behind with authority, you need to know where the grids are and metronome practice is crucial. I'm not that great at timing either, so I'm trying to do as much reps in with metronomes as I can. Learning to play on the grid is a first step before learning how to deviate with clear intention. I hope this helps!

author: Gazing Wrmth | Mixes & Masters
content:
Hey @louisvie
I hope I'm not late for the reply but Here are some workflow tips(with an assumption that you are doing foley first time).
1.Download Your Sounds from https://sonniss.com/gameaudiogdc . They have almost 150-160 GB's of free Library of Pre Recorded sound which are royalty free which has almost everything  you'll need.
2. Download Soundly(it's Free) and Use it as your Sample Browser for faster workflow as it's search functionality is specifically designed for searching foley sound,sfx,ambience etc(make Sure to Run it as Administrator for windows or it won't drag sounds to ableton) .
3. Run Ableton in Gridless Mode for perfect timings for placing foley.
4. Make sure to level and organise similer sounds together on the Go as it will help in later stages for sending stems for mixing.
5. Going Scene by scene helps for preventing the overwhelm of the Huge Film.
and all the Best for this Gig🍻

At the end of the day, if you don’t make a song that does well enough you’re probably not going to have to worry about people booking you much anyway. I don’t know a single person in town who’s like, “I’m paying this guy for session after session even though he never delivers results but man is he a fun hang”.

Again, the job of the producer really comes down to maximizing the strengths and minimizing the weaknesses. That doesn’t just apply to a kick sound.

author: Deleted User
content:
I’d like to challenge the idea of “the performance you need”. Do you need it? Who needs it more? 

As a producer, you’re gonna have another project soon. And you can even remove it from your discography playlist if you really don’t want people listening to it. BUT Artists have to live with the record. 

What I believe is that there’s performance that both the artist and I need. And that is an honest performance. If there are things that can be addressed easily and quickly, by all means go for it. But it’s still important to be careful to not let that inject any doubts in the performers. I fuck up on this all the time, even though I fuck up less the more I do it- it’s still not an easy thing to do. It’s not even a person to person thing.. it’s a moment to moment thing. I find it necessary to gauge how they are feeling and what else is going on in their minds and lives that may be getting in the way of being at their best. A 15 minute conversation may serve the session better than doing 15 minutes of more takes.

author: Slow Hand
content:
I'll add two things here:

**1.** If a session relies on shared samples or IRs then both you and your partner should get in the habit of habitually doing a *Collect All and Save* before you close out the session. Every time.

This way the samples travel with the session and your partner does not have to go searching. **The assets should always be saved with the session.**

**2.** Move the date (YYMMDD) to the front of all file names, such as sessions and renders.

File names will look something like this:

260214 Track title
260214 Track title v2
260215 Track title (vocal editing)
260216 NEW track title (160 bpm)

This way your assets are always filed chronologically and there is no question which version is the most recent version. It's always at the end of the list.

In this case we had effects/elements from the first song pop up later on in the second song.) I left blank space in the second song’s bounce so they could be lined up perfectly. author: Slow Hand
content:
As a practical example of when not being in phase is the right move:

Jon Castelli did a live mix on Twitch on Wednesday that included live drums. He identified that one of the snare mics sounded fuller when he inverted the polarity and proceeded to mix with that. 

Later in that session when it came time for notes, the producer (who was present in the room) asked why the snare had lost a certain thin and "woody" character that they liked. Jon reverted the snare mic to it's original polarity and the producer went "Ahh! There it is."

So the takeaway here is that while drums usually *do* sing the best and hit the hardest when they're all working in phase with one another, sometimes the creative intention overrides the need to align them in a way that makes them most "full".

As you say: If it sounds good, it is good.

author: Slow Hand
content:
If you're concerned about being too suggestive to the players about their parts then strip back the demo until it contains only the most essential parts. No fancy stuff. Just chords, melody, and lyric. *Maybe* a kick drum pattern. Lead sheet style.

If the song is good then it will still be compelling. The best songs tend to be very robust and can be played a dozen different ways because they are fundamentally compelling. If the demo doesn't feel good this way then the song may need more work.

Lesser songs will depend on the arrangement or production to be compelling, or only work in a narrow band of styles. Sometimes a song can only work one way. It's okay if this is the case for your song, but then it's up to you to present the demo with the arrangement or elements that are essential to make the song compelling, and that will close off more and more of the instrumental possibilities.

So if you want to increase the chances of a session player delivering an unexpected, brilliant, idea then set them up for success with a strong song that can be interpreted many ways.

----

author: Zack Hames
content:
I’m probably an outlier in the usual drum pack consumer but I’ll give you my take:

1. I found when there’s a million samples I get uninterested quickly. I’d prefer 2 snare sounds as opposed to 15 slight variations of nearly the same thing.

2. I use an MPC, so the lower volume thing would be annoying for my personal use, but that’s an outlier.

3. You could farm out the Battery / Kontakt / etc packs to friends who would be willing to do it or use those tools a lot, that way you’re not stuck making a ton of them (unless you want to of course) 

4. I don’t touch loops usually but I know tons of others do. 

5. That’s it. Sounds like a super fun and badass project! You should document it on the way on the discord

Edit: I’m speaking to more electronic and supplemental use of drum samples. There are probably tons of folks out there who want all the options as if there was 100% a real drummer recorded in their studio.

author: Slow Hand
content:
I've always loved Vulfpeck's approach. For the first few albums every single tracking take was filmed on an iPhone while they recorded in their living room/bedroom/etc, which allowed Jack Stratton to turn around and release low budget music videos for every single song on the album using the take that made the album.

Their setup was always lo-fi and charmingly janky in the edit. They just leaned into the artifice of a low-grade camera and built their whole visual style around these simple phone captures of the session.

author: Slow Hand
content:
A few things:

1. What kind of samples are we talking about syncing here? Short samples like drums and loops? Or heavy sampled instruments like a piano/string library? Or both? 

2. I think the equivalent syncing feature in Dropbox would be "make available offline". If you right click a folder and "make available offline" it will continually update when it receives uploads from the other computer. Have you used that before? It doesn't have the lightning speed of a local network/ethernet connection, but if you can wait a few minutes it's good.

3. I assume these are Ableton sessions. Do you ever use the 'collect all and save' feature when saving sessions? It will gather every external sample (but not sampled instrument libraries) and save them to the project folder, which will save you the trouble of having to point your Ableton session to any external directory, because it will all be in the project folder. Very good when it comes to archiving sessions and opening them up years later.

author: Deleted User
content:
the controller is called continuum. I believe it is an mpe (midi polyphonic expressions) device. I don’t know much about kyma but i would look into physical modeling because this is what the sound generation is based on. A lot of physical modeling is heavily based on delay lines, so I’d start there. Modal synthesis is also another cool concept where you would feed an impulse sample into a bank of parallel bandpass filters (very narrow q- which is also constructed with delay lines fundamentally). The idea is feedback and resonance from the filters would emulate acoustic modes. 

You can emulate this with fairly cheap stuff like leap motion, I’ve done a different project (something much simpler) with leap motion for gesture controlled music concrète. But you can definitely use the gestures to do the same thing with physical modeling. I’d be down to work on something together if you’re interested!

author: delwin
content:
I do this a lot!

In Ableton, you have soooo many options. Most often I put the sample on an Ableton Simpler and am able to slice / pitch / etc really fluidly — record that, and then edit by hand. This is my workflow for 90% of vocal chops. If it’s really simple I’ll do it by hand but I find I get more musical results if I can “play” the chop. 

There’s also Buffer Shuffler and Beat Repeat in Ableton which can be fun and unpredictable. 

The Glitch Machines plugins are also really nice if you’re going for something a bit crazy (two of them are free and very good). I don’t fully understand them yet so I just throw them on when I want something wacky to happen. 

And I’ll also second stutter edit — very fun for “playing” chops live too, and editing presets isn’t too hard either.

I don’t have a specific question but am more curious to discuss the topic  and hear other folks experience. Could go many diff directions.. how do we facilitate those ‘special’ moments with session players? Which I like the idea of getting the piece you know you want or need first and then playing the rest of the time. Or how to communicate and prevent really good players from over powering a song and doing too much? For this project I chose to leave a lot of room for the players to play and write their own parts, but I also needed to reel them in a little bit and simplify what was happening. Even then when I dug through the tracks I had to mute certain fills, take a simpler pass of the keys to let the bass do it’s thing or vice versa. author: Slow Hand
content:
Totally. 

So I should clarify a little bit. These 3-4 patches aren't static sounds that I never change. Think of them more like initialized synth templates with pre-determined routings and modulation that I can start with and then diverge from. I still use other people's presets, but using these templates can save me a good 15 minutes every time that I want to build a new patch and don't want to start all the way from scratch. They come with a lot of built-in expression.

On most of these I've got a lot of the keyboard tracking already tuned so that a bright patch doesn't get too harsh as I go up in register or it doesn't get too flabby and lose definition in the low-end.

I've got one patch set up for very expressive pitch modulation. Lots of big sweeps and bends in the attack/release envelope phases. Think wonky Neptunes-type sounds or two-octave dive bombs. Stuff like that.

One patch is set for expressive filter and amplitude modulation. Wobbles, envelope modulations, and such. It's my go-to if I'm trying to play with some "brassy" dynamics.

One is a legato mono patch for very fluid vocal-like playing. A big emphasis on note articulation and variation. I think of it as a solo instrument.

The final one is (you called it) A nice poly synth. Think James Blake on a Prophet. Pretty standard stuff, but once again it's got keyboard tracking that's tuned up so that the patch feels rich across the entire range.

author: Deleted User
content:
Playing it or you can take a drum loop with groove you like and map out a groove template. Playing it is much faster and more feel, but often times it will need editing unless you have great timing. If it’s something loose then I’d definitely go ahead and move each notes because quantizing even 50% is going to change the feel. This is real nerdy but when there’s a really good moment in groove, I use logic’s event editor to look at how many ticks they are off by and snap other notes to somewhere near. For example, if I liked the feel of it being 40 ticks late then I’m gonna move everything (or some select notes that are in the same spot of the groove cycle) to somewhere nearby. Ticks are tempo relative so 50 ticks in 90bpm is different than 50 ticks in 120bpm. But it’s still in same relative timeline, but it’s going to feel different in different tempos. 

If you want it to groove like a drummer played it, best thing to do is play it in. You might end up quantizing or fixing velocity to al 127 later, but it’s going to be better than clicked in sequence if that is the style. Clicked in sequenced drums is its own groove too, you don’t want them having looseness so you quantize them all to 0 but you can still mess around with nudging them to be a bit behind or ahead of the grid.

author: Nick Hatzakos
Ross Fortune
content:
1) what are the top 5 most important things for you in purchasing a drum sample pack ?


I never purchase drum sample packs - not since having Splice. I do like a clear identity in a pack though - for instance, The Kount's sample pack has all those lo-fi/saturated kicks and snares, wonky grooves and crusty hi hats etc that sit very much in his genre, so if I'm reaching for that sound, I know exactly where to go. 

I don't know your drummer or his band, but I'd wonder what distinctive character you could capture in your pack? So that I know exactly where to go when I want "that" sound in a writing session instant. 


2) I’m always annoyed that all samples are 0.0db normalized and I always have to turned them way down to keep my gain staging coherent, would I be crazy to have them peak at -8 ? Would people automatically hate it ? 

I produce largely in Ableton now, and when you drop a sample in the drum rack, the instance of Simpler it creates defaults to -12dB. With the velocity:volume dial at default (45%), this causes a 0dB sample to play back at -6dB when velocity=100 (the default). My template has all mixer faders (including a basic drum rack + instance of Drum Buss) trimmed to -9dB (similar to my mix gain staging strategy I detailed previously), allowing me to mash stuff up if needed, and still have headroom to not have to max out vocals when it comes to cutting them. What I'm saying in a roundabout way is... I've already made allowances for 0dB samples, so I don't care - but you probably should, because if you're selling on Splice, they could sound dwarfed against the next pack.

author: spectrummasters
content: With regards to making a call , I’d be interested in peoples perspectives . How do you make the call between following an artists ideas and helping them to articulate those ideas vs following your own instincts  that it’s time to move the process on and finish adding ideas in order to resolve and complete ? Ie . Recently I completed a project to master with an artist who was over the moon , planning the video ….no complaints , pure buzz , a few weeks later . I get the message “hey man I was just thinking what if we try and add a piano part “ . Imo the song doesn’t demand it , I suspect friends and armchair mozarts have thrown in their own 2 pence in the last few weeks and now what was in all our opinions 🔥, has to face tinkering . I don’t like telling people what to think , ie . I think you’re making a mistake …..but I don’t like overwriting songs , so for me it’s a obvious f that idea let’s just write another one  . I’d be interested in others internal dialogue with regards to when / if/ how you say no ….and if it sits with you alright personally or you find it problematic (and I ask this in order to find charming but assertive ways to keep the door closed on a project when it truly felt  finished to all involved  and went to full completion / master and release strategy and now as the producer you truly believe it can only be damaged by changes )

content:
My MPC Live is my right hand man in the studio as a writing tool. But when im NOT making records and mixing and recording, I make industrial music entirely on hardware. So the MPC is the daw in this case. No computer. 

If I’m using the MPC on a production where it isn’t the brain, it gets a little cumbersome, sometimes I make stuff on it and simply record it analog into pro tools. Other times I actually export the “stems” on the MPC as it’s very easy then take the sd card and drop the files into the session. This is a little time consuming but works and sounds great. 

There is MPC software/plugin that works with it! I just haven’t integrated it with my daw yet, but it seems legit. 

I don’t program drums on a piano roll ever, I always hit the pads.

author: Deleted User
content:
it’s generally the orange if it’s something like palm muted guitars. But always listen and feel it. It can feel better to be early in certain styles but it can feel better to be late on other styles. it also depends on who else is doing what

But groove template is always there if you wanna line it up with other instruments. bounce and make the source and destination audio files the same length, make sure the markers are in the correct place then sync them up. 

I’m 90% manual editing though. Because aligning automatically can fix notes I didn’t want to fix. you can also go measure by measure to be more careful if you want to auto align with groove templates 

you want to ask yourself “is this note late or early?” before making any moves. I like nudging with keyboard so I can fine tune how far it goes. 

Nowadays I’m more committed to “the only way to make the groove feel good is to play it that way”. I hate having to edit and to be honest, nothing beats well played rhythm section… Especially because I do a lot of in between the groove stuff, 30% quantization can mess with the feel of well landed notes. So I’m doing a lot of metronome practice these days

author: LAPhill
content:
MTC and MMC are likely your best bets. But MIDI is not sample accurate, so you can expect some milliseconds of drift at least, different each time you hit play. Might be fine for coming up with parts, but it’s not a great solution for a whole project. 

The only tech I’ve seen that gets around that is Avid’s Satellite Link, but that’s just for syncing Pro Tools rigs.

For sure. Even the greatest session musicians I grew up listening to don’t play it technically at all times. But the first vibey take is gonna be better as I get my chops up. 

In my definition, one take musician still applies as long as I don’t NEED to record another take after the first one. if the first take doesn’t have anything that throws the listener off from feeling the music, that’s as good as I want to be. I’m not crazy about not needing punch ins or comps. 

@popaganda. that’s where Ruairi’s listen like a 15yo girl probably comes in. I’m often listening as myself, I don’t know how to listen outside of my own self. 

Larry Klein said “I usually don’t play bass on my records because it makes me listen as a bassist”. Perspective is everything, and it really can’t be faked or bought. Posing a question to myself to open up to different perspectives is huge

author: Deleted User
content:
re: 1 

I have gotten over the whole “perfectionism” thing. I still overthink all the time but I can confidently day I am free of perfectionism. I have no problem letting go when it calls for it. I believe there’s a difference between wanting to be better and working towards it vs not being able to move on out of fear and holding onto something without knowing the next move. If that was the case I wouldn’t have sent what I first recorded to the artist. I may have wasted some time thinking I would be able to get this part down, but I don’t think I was being a perfectionist by doing that. 

re: 2

Why would he do this if he’s a great guitarist? Is it a workflow preference or the aesthetic of edit/sampling? I can only imagine it being faster playing the parts in rather than stitching bits together. 



The whole goal is to be able to consistently reproduce that magical groove, and being able to create great moments when I am with other people. I really believe I have a good sense of groove but can’t execute it just yet. 

I can see myself spending countless hours editing myself. (Which I already do daily). That time is better spent working on my chops. If I can hire other musicians so I can stop wasting time trying multiple takes, I would. But I don’t have that just yet. I go by sections or measures most of the time, I don’t just sit there trying to nail ONE perfect take.

Art is subjective, so there’s actually no “better” — This is something I need to remind myself of more. The amount of times that I showed something that I thought was good and was rejected, and the times I showed something I hated and got good reactions from  people. You really never know! 

I’ve been doing more writing sessions these days (once or twice a week or so), and I’m really falling in love with this because I can get out of my own head and look around to get a sense of whether an idea is working or not outside of my own opinions

Speaking of the relentless will to finish: would it be a producer’s job to stay on top of getting others in team to get their parts done? If I’ve done my part already and completed it, do I keep bothering them to get their parts done? (lyrics etc) 

I read your reply to someone asking about writing sessions, and you said your biggest goal is to get the vocals from the first spark of inspiration on that same day. I’ve had sessions where I get a basic bone of ideas with beat done, and top line is done but the lyrics are recorded in Gibberish and stream of consciousness. I would return, complete the arrangement on my own - send it back, they said they fuck with it and tells me they will finish the lyrics. How long do I wait, do I follow up at all, or do I just move on and keep making more? I don’t want to overstep or rush people (and.. I can’t get anyone to anything of course), but I also want to get the song done while I’m excited so I can keep moving forward. It’s hard to tell if I can even do about it or if I should just keep it moving and leave it be

author: Slow Hand
content:
Yeah. I'm asking if you want samples of solo string instruments or a string section.

For ensemble I've been enjoying the *NI Session Strings 2*. I've also got the *Spitfire BBC Symphony* but I'm less fond of those because they're recorded from an orchestral perspective and have a lot of room sound baked in, whereas *Session Strings 2* have a closer perspective. If you want an ensemble sound plus some major grit and close-miking I *do* like the *Bernard Hermann* orchestral library from Spitfire.

For solo strings the *NI Cremona Quartet* instruments are really, really nice. They're a pleasure to play with and sound fantastic. These have maximum presence too, so you can get some very direct sounds with them. I'm really enjoying them. The articulation and tonal options are extremely thorough.

A while back a few people recommended *Sunset Strings* by Realitone. While I haven't used it yet, they look very promising. They seem to be serving people who want a rock/pop string feel, which could be just the ticket.

author: Adam Thein
content:
The only way I trust time editing multitrack sources like drums in Ableton is linking the channels (right click menu option when you have multiple tracks selected) and like Josh said slicing manually in front of each transient and sliding the audio to where you’d like it to be.

Other daws are much better suited to automating this workflow like Beat Detective in Pro Tools or a similar style workflow in Logic I forget the name of.  Studio one has a similar workflow that I also forget the name of.

author: louisvie
content:
Hi everyone, here's the situation for me right now 

Singer/Artist/Band Leader wants to release big single with video in 4 days to coincide with band's concert. (In important small venue in Paris, FR (hometown) friends will be there, big event he rightly envisions as a celebration for the new kick-ass song with the new kick-ass video.)

But, as close friend, band-in-question-member, sound guy and producer for the project, I think we should wait and take time to get very good vocals, while right now it feels like they're merely existing because song has to have vocals. Leaves no strong impression, or the impression that the performance lacks intention.

Band rocks (his guitar included), Harmonies and Gang Vocals are cool. 
Really the lead vocal is the only thing in the way of getting the song to be really good. 

On the one hand, I feel like his intuition for the release date (deadline is in 4 days) is good and could be very valuable for us.
On the other, I don't see why anyone would be truly excited for us if singer is mid.
(I know he's good deep down, he's given me chills when singing with no pressure, rn we're just lacking some of that magic.)

As the song is today, you wouldn't love to listen to the song on your way to work or school, enjoying it for what it is.

Anyway, right now I'm going to try and squeeze that magic out of him in the next following days when we can see each other.
As I'm typing this I also realize I should send him the instrumental and let him try shit alone. 

Maybe that's my answer.

author: cy (sigh)
content:
I produce /write  and mix. 
I'd say about 60% mix work but mostly cause the production stuff tends to make longer w my clients. 

I have no issues jumping from project to project but I personally HAVE TO have all ny task organized and planned in my head.  so either the night before or when I wake up (at 3am usually) I'll organize my tasks on Notion based on project urgency etc and pick 3 things I have to do and 3 things I'd like to do 

from then I just make sure to jump between what I have to do whenever I feel like there's no forward movement on something. the 3 extra things are backups that I jump to in case I'm really uninspired w the others for some reason.

I will say I use a timer to take 5-15mns breaks regularly and will often do short workouts to get the blood flowing which I find helps me maintain more consistent energy on long hauls 

if it's production work specifically I'll write down the tasks as specifically as possible and try to hits check point whiting 20-30mns if the goal is spcific enough,

author: markmaclure
content:
Anyone have any tips on working with new artists/producers with no filter? Like where they NEED to try out every idea they have, even if it's not good, or if it's a bad time (ie we're tracking guitars and they stop everyone to try out a (bad) bass idea). 

I'm on a project right now where a new artist is bringing their songwriting partner to every session as a producer. This is their first production gig (which is fine), but we're wasting a lot of time on ideas that get scrapped later on. This person has a good ear, and occasionally has GREAT ideas, but it takes forever for them to let go of bad ideas. 

It takes all of my patience to very slowly walk them through why the ideas aren't working, and there's a lot of pushback when I do. A lot of "but can we just try it? I really feel like it will work" then 3 hours later "oh yeah I think you were right let's delete it".

author: Juliette
content:
Hey guys! Hope everyone is doing well. I have a question— when setting up to record vocals, what levels do you generally let the volume peak at, and how does one work with dynamic performances? And a specific question: what should I keep the gain at on my interface?

This recent project has a very whisper-like vocal section that requires a little more gain, and then a lot of loud vocals that require less gain. 

This ends up leaving me having to either turn up the clip gain during mixing or turning up the bus, which leads to clipping. Or (something I really don’t like, because I tend to hear it a lot more) is adjusting the gain while tracking sections. There’s certainly a way to navigate this seamlessly, but I just don’t know it yet :stare:

author: cian riordan
content: Doing all the tedious clip gaining work is just part of the process these days… you’ll get faster and more comfortable with it down the road and your workflow will speed up significantly

author: Deleted User
content:
I want to chime in here, I mostly agree with what the others said and as long as you don’t unintentionally clip all is well. But I think we can dig a bit deeper.

I like to work in a way during tracking/production that’s maybe a bit more old school with shooting for around -18dbFS on the average. It gives me a kind of fixed reference in my mind which gives me enough headroom for most dynamics. Now the important part is you have to turn up your monitoring/headphones volume to be adequately loud to work with those lower levels and then leave it there.That being said it might be necessary to bring down other pre existing tracks that are too loud.

Now since the volume of the monitoring/headphones stays the same during that tracking session you can use the gain of your preamp (or the output gain of the compressor, if you’re using one on the way in) to adjust the vocal or instrument so that for every part of the arrangement it feels right. So in a sense you are pre mixing during the recording, taking off some work down the line

author: cian riordan
content: I mean this is a workflow… but I don’t see any advantages of any other level to shoot for that’s under 0dBFS? Why not -6? -8? Also having your monitors cranked that loud is a bit scary for me as one wrong input switch or one accidental fader zeroing and you could be taking your head off.

author: cian riordan
content: Just seems like more work to adhere to an arbitrary -18dBFS standard than just track at whatever level makes sense for the session and just make sure nothing clips.

author: Juliette
content:
I've had a thought bouncing around my head in a bit, and I think it's been a big issue for me of the late as to why I'm getting stuck on completing my projects. I'm still learning and un-learning good habits and bad habits, and developing skills as to what's right and wrong when it comes to producing and mixing. But I think something I'm struggling with right now is knowing whether or not the production process was not good or the mix process was not good, based on the sound of the final product.

I've really dove deep into learning how to mix in the last two years and definitely improved, but in terms of production, I think I'm still quite intimidated by what the first go-round sounds like and get frustrated. Covid times showed me that getting really good sound is possible in the comfort of your own space, and it was reassuring. But then at the end of a project, I'm like "Well, I've done everything they did, why doesn't mine sound like that?" (Comparison is the thief of joy, I know :sadcowboy: ). And I'm left wondering, is it my gear, is it my space, is it my interface, is it my DAW, is it my mix, is it my master?

And then this begs my other question, even if they production was not necessarily "A tier", just how much can mixing fix it?

I think I'm just curious as to what I can do to optimize my production process as much as possible, mixing aside, so that way I at least know that it's not something from the tracking process I need to go back fix.

author: Juliette
content:
Something that I’m realizing that kind of screwed me a bit is that I grew up playing and recording a lot of heavy metal, and that turned into hours and hours of trying to perfect the method to get a huge, heavy song. I’ve watched quite a bit of Joey Sturgis, Fredrik Nordstrom, Zakk Cervini, Jordan Fish, Dan Weller, Will Putney— and the production/mix process became very technical at times, and that’s what I stuck with when it came to my projects as well. 

Delving into other genres has been extremely fun but my brain is still used to trying to be super technical rather than just enjoy the sound. :sigh:

author: JakeTB

Ableton has lots of workflows- how are doing your programming?

The playback should be the same as any other daw, but there are a couple traps that come up.

author: Will Trotman
content: If it's two equal leads with no center, I always find hard panning to sound a little disconnected. I tend to keep them pretty narrow like 20% off to either side. I also find that any way you can process them differently from one another is helpful to avoid any phasing issues (i.e. make one darker, one brighter, de ess one harder, compress them differently, only tune one). Recently on a project I had two leads and ended up keeping one center as a main lead and one off to the side a good bit quieter and darker, more ambiance. Ended up digging that way more than i expected and was surprised it didn't feel unbalanced

author: Slow Hand
content:
Oh I certainly feel that. 

I'll often find myself making records that start to fall into three or four different buckets (ex: heavy stuff, singer songwriter, experimental, etc...). I start grouping together the tracks that feel complimentary and then when I have enough they'll start to suggest a direction for an album, at which point I'll focus on that larger project until it's complete.

Then I jump back into the songs in the remaining buckets and use them as the jumping off point for the next release. That's one way to do it.

author: Zack Hames
content: Does anyone have any Sampler plugin alternatives they prefer over Battery? It *works* but I have constantly struggled with the workflow and the way everything is set up by default (and seemingly can't be changed). It slows me down dramatically.

author: Zack Hames
content:
here's the workflow:

I don't use many of the preset kits anymore. Just not really the sounds I'm looking for. I have a massive library of samples that i like to use. Accessing those is easy.
The problem is I don't make preset kits. Every session, every kit, is a different combination of things, always starting fresh. So I am in the Library view constantly going through samples/files to load into any Cell of Battery.

When I find a sound I like, I can click it or drag it to the cell I want. This is all great.

But, the second i drop it in, I have to change the velocity from 0-100% (I saved my default preset to have all cells at 0% velocity which seems to be working). and then *every time i add a new sample or replace a sample* it makes it a loop in the "Editor" window. There is no shortcut, no preference, no saving a preset, that allows me to essentially remove that behavior.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
And not just for making things incrementally better, but for solving problems as well.

I recently was mixing a song with a young mixer who I gave my session to. I heard a very subtle low and thump after two particular downbeat and we could not figure out what it was. We solo'ed some groups and then I remembered that he had replicated my autotune settings on the bass guitar (he had a slightly different version). I know from lots of tuning experience that different modes will occasionally cause different types of artifacts. So we solo'ed the bass, switched from "modern" (his default) to "classic" and it was solved.

author: spectrummasters
content:
One of the most helpful things to break out of the 4/8 bar loop of death is to begin your project with the audio file of a track you love the arrangement for imported . 

Mute it and set your project to its tempo (it’s just easier ) 

Now get to jamming away 

Once you’ve built the loop you adore , 
Mute it 

Listen again from top to bottom the track you love the arrangements for . 

Listen to how the different elements come in and out , where , how . 

How are the motifs evolved . Any counter melody / rythms .

Drops and breakdowns 

Make notes of it all . 
Then copy it exactly or to the degree you want with your own elements of your loop . 

Voila . You made a fully arranged track . 

Repeat

author: Akanksha
content:
Right now if I hear a particular lead sound I would start fiddling with serum's knobs just to recreate it perfectly for hours only to get frustrated in the end that I didn't actually put anything much to listen to in my session. 

I don't think it's a waste of time because every time I do this, I feel that I get better with my understanding of sound design. 

But I believe that I need to find a balance between learning and making something of my own. 
I tend to feel lost often if I can't make things exactly how I hear them in my head. 

I guess I have to embrace my imperfections as I'm still a beginner. 
I'm going to replicate the sounds and structure I love, but I'm not going to make it sound perfect, like the original as I can't do it yet. 
It'll be a learning session for me.

author: longstoryshort
content:
one of my earlier experiences writing for other people (ghost producing for a few DJs) in that same kinda lane, future bass ish

i used to produce before i would *write* sometimes, and the energy would just get sucked right out of the room

as soon i opened serum they'd say oh we're not getting a record done today

that moment really hurt me at that time, but later on i realized it was true - it's always the true criticism that really hits, right?

so i made adjustments by building out my sounds/library/synth patches in advance, so when sessions came up i would be able to just fire in 90% of the way done sounds.

when the song was written then i'd finish up the sounds and do the tweaking and the session had so much momentum it didn't take long to finish.

records got done, money was made, everyone was happier.

author: Akanksha
content:
you're so right
sometimes we fail to understand the difference between creative exploration and being stuck in the process of creation.

I also have let go of my habit of watching endless tutorials before starting a session. I especially dislike going down the rabbit hole of  those "50 advanced production tricks to level up your sound" videos. It's like why am I watching this instead of creating some actual music first?

yes, creating a bank of samples and sounds beforehand is the way to go. 
On those days, I'll just spend my time doing sound design and exploring sounds that fit the genre. 

I've realised that scheduling and managing time well is important, even in music.

Btw, did you talk about the vibe and atmosphere of the track in advance with your clients in order to do better sound selection for the style they wanted to go for?

author: austenballard
content:
so for ableton specifically since it doesn't have alts, when I'm collabing with someone we'll make sure we each save versions using name and date so for example

SongTitle_Austen_v01_260218.als
SongTitle_AustensFriend_v02_260218.als

etc, etc, etc

also if you need a shared library of samples or IRs or something an app like SoundQ is indispensible

once you get to PT you can do the same system for the .ptx session files ... OR go playlist crazy

I do most mixing in logic so alts

author: austenballard
content:
I also really like to get hyper-organized inside the project folders so I make a folder for bounces, a folder for committed trackouts (which i prefer vs freeze/flatten, but do it however it works for you), and then folders for ancillary stuff like lead sheets, lyric sheets, etc

also make sure you each bounce after each version

also helps to freeze (but not flatten) in case your collaborator doesn't have the same plugins or presets or whatever so you can keep rolling back and forth even if you're using different plugins

author: sethearnest
content:
I’ve been doing this a lot with a buddy. We house everything in DB as the “master” session then each backup to our own backup systems. 

One thing we’ve noticed is that PT seems less happy working out of DB on our rigs — I’m going to experiment with “pausing sync” in DB next time we get into a heavy session as we’re actually working to see if that helps. 

But generally has worked great aside from a slight performance dip (which doesn’t seem to affect some other people as much, so maybe it’s just our own rigs’ issues). And general best practices of Save-As’ing often have proven important as we’re both working on various things so we’re not messing up each other’s work/sessions.
